docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan detoured from the campaign trail to vote on a measure that will avoid a government default and an election-season battle.

headline.main: House Republicans Welcome Back Ryan, and His Vote, on a Spending Measure
headline.print_headline: House Republicans Welcome Back Ryan, and His Vote, on a Spending Measure

docs.abstract: Rep Paul D Ryan returns to the House to vote on stopgap spending measure, which easily passes, 329 to 91, following Ryan's approval; smooth passage of the bill is a marked departure from the budget fights that threatened to shut down the government in 2011, with the approaching election and the political threat of another debilitating showdown overwhelming Republican instincts for a fight.
docs.snippet: Representative Paul D. Ryan detoured from the campaign trail to vote on a measure that will avoid a government default and an election-season battle.

docs.lead_paragraph: We need to improve the state of our schools for health professionals, to fill needs at home and reduce the flood of imported health workers, who are needed in their own countries.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Kate Tulenko argues that America needs to improve the state of schools for health professionals, which have failed to increase their efficiency and output despite rapidly rising demand; notes that the US now imports about 12 percent of its health care work force at a high cost from other countries, largely due to excessive regulations and unnecessarily high credential requirements for domestic workers.
docs.snippet: We need to improve the state of our schools for health professionals, to fill needs at home and reduce the flood of imported health workers, who are needed in their own countries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reports that progress was being made helped build hope that the city’s public schools could reopen on Monday.

headline.seo: Both Sides in Chicago Teachers’ Strike Adopt Upbeat Tone
headline.main: Fresh Hopes for End to Chicago Teacher Strike by Weekend
headline.print_headline: Four Days Into Chicago Teachers’ Strike, Both Sides Adopt Upbeat Tone

docs.abstract: Leaders on both sides of Chicago's teacher strike voice optimism that a deal could soon be reached, bringing an end to the walkout that has halted classes for 350,000 students in the nation's third-largest school system.
docs.snippet: Reports that progress was being made helped build hope that the city’s public schools could reopen on Monday.

byline.contributor: Steven Greenhouse contributed reporting from New York.
byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and STEVEN YACCINO

headline.main: 4 Years After Lehman's Demise, Regulators Debate Overhaul

docs.abstract: Mark Wetjen, a Democratic member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, told an industry group that the agency was debating how to crack down on foreign derivatives trading.
docs.snippet: Mark Wetjen, a Democratic member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, told an industry group that the agency was debating how to crack down on foreign derivatives trading.

headline.main: Children of Aging Parents Are Often Nearby, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Many adult children struggle to provide care from afar, but recent research suggests that distance may be less a problem than once thought.
docs.snippet: Many adult children struggle to provide care from afar, but recent research suggests that distance may be less a problem than once thought.

headline.main: Living With Cancer: The Trials of Cancer Trials

docs.abstract: There are many trials associated with enrolling in a cancer trial. Patients can fail to qualify, or later they can be thrown out or end up in a group that doesn’t get the drug. There are also challenges of geography and timing. But for some of us, a clinical trial is our best hope for living a little bit longer.

headline.main: Many Struggling With Prescription Drug Costs

docs.abstract: Nearly half of American adults take prescription drugs, a new report finds.
docs.snippet: Nearly half of American adults take prescription drugs, a new report finds.
